title: Why a total solar eclipse is such a big deal

multiple-choice.question: What is a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: A lunar eclipse that occurs when the Earth's shadow falls on the moon.

options.label: B
options.text: A solar eclipse that occurs when the moon's shadow falls on the surface of the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: A partial eclipse that occurs when the moon's shadow partially covers the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: A lunar eclipse that occurs when the moon passes between the Earth and the sun.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we get eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the moon's orbit is in line with the Earth's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: Because there are two points where the moon's orbit crosses the sun's plane, called nodes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Earth's shadow falls on the moon most months.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon's shadow falls on the surface of the Earth most months.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the moon often turns red during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the shorter bluer wavelengths of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the moon's orbit is tilted about 5 degrees.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon's size varies about 12% throughout a month.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to predict eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the moon's orbit is in line with the Earth's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: Because there are a ton of orbital quirks that make predicting eclipses really complicated.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Earth's shadow falls on the moon most months.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon's shadow falls on the surface of the Earth most months.

multiple-choice.question: What will happen to the frequency of total solar eclipses in the far future?

options.label: A
options.text: They will become more frequent.

options.label: B
options.text: They will remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: They will become less frequent because the moon is moving further away from the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: They will become more rare because the moon's size varies about 12% throughout a month.

options.label: D

title: Why do people join cults? - Janja Lalich

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of a cult that is often used to describe its behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: A cult is a group or movement with a shared commitment to a usually extreme ideology that's typically embodied in a charismatic leader.

options.label: B
options.text: A cult is a group or movement that is focused on self-improvement and personal growth.

options.label: C
options.text: A cult is a group or movement that is led by a charismatic leader and has a strict hierarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: A cult is a group or movement that is focused on worship and the cultivation of certain gods.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that cults are able to recruit new members?

options.label: A
options.text: By using social media to advertise their beliefs and practices.

options.label: B
options.text: By targeting people who are new to an area or who have recently undergone some personal or professional loss.

options.label: C
options.text: By using formal and informal systems of influence and control to keep members obedient.

options.label: D
options.text: By providing answers to life's biggest questions through their doctrine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the internal conflict that occurs when a person is unable to reconcile their doubts about a cult with their desire to belong?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive dissonance

options.label: B
options.text: Emotional dissonance

options.label: C
options.text: Psychological dissonance

options.label: D
options.text: Social dissonance

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that cults are able to maintain control over their members?

options.label: A
options.text: By using formal and informal systems of influence and control to keep members obedient.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing answers to life's biggest questions through their doctrine.

options.label: C
options.text: By using techniques of coercive persuasion involving guilt, shame, and fear.

options.label: D
options.text: By denying basic freedoms of thought, speech, and association.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that cults are able to harm their members?

options.label: A
options.text: By denying basic freedoms of thought, speech, and association.

options.label: B
options.text: By using techniques of coercive persuasion involving guilt, shame, and fear.

options.label: C
options.text: By providing answers to life's biggest questions through their doctrine.

options.label: D
options.text: By targeting those who are new to an area or who have recently undergone some personal or professional loss.

title: Why babies in medieval paintings look like ugly old men

multiple-choice.question: Why do medieval babies in art appear to be ugly?

options.label: A
options.text: Because medieval artists were bad at drawing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were influenced by the idea of the homunculus, which is Latin for little man.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were trying to depict the hardships of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were trying to be humorous.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the change in style from ugly medieval babies to cute Renaissance babies?

options.label: A
options.text: The Renaissance was a time of great poverty, and people couldn't afford to paint beautiful babies.

options.label: B
options.text: The Renaissance was a time of great wealth, and people could afford to paint beautiful babies.

options.label: C
options.text: The Renaissance was a time of great cultural exchange, and people were influenced by Greek and Roman art.

options.label: D
options.text: The Renaissance was a time of great technological advancement, and people could use new techniques to paint beautiful babies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the idea that Jesus was born perfectly formed and unchanged?

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of the homunculus.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea of the immaculate conception.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion of the divine child.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of the little man.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Renaissance artists change their depiction of baby Jesus from an ugly homunculus to a cute chubby baby?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were trying to depict the hardships of life.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were influenced by the idea of the homunculus, which is Latin for little man.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were trying to fit the idealized forms of Greek and Roman art.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were trying to be humorous.

multiple-choice.question: What is the modern ideal for depicting babies in art?

options.label: A
options.text: As ugly, homunculus-like creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: As cute, chubby, and adorable.

options.label: C
options.text: As abstract, modernist forms.

options.label: D
options.text: As realistic, photorealistic images.

title: Why don't perpetual motion machines ever work? - Netta Schramm

multiple-choice.question: Who designed one of the earliest designs for a perpetual motion machine, a device that can do work indefinitely without any external energy source?

options.label: A
options.text: Robert Boyle

options.label: B
options.text: Bhaskara the Learned

options.label: C
options.text: Charles Darwin

options.label: D
options.text: Isaac Newton

multiple-choice.question: What is the first law of thermodynamics that prevents a perpetual motion machine from working?

options.label: A
options.text: Energy can't be destroyed, only transformed.

options.label: B
options.text: Energy can't be created or destroyed, you can only get out as much energy as you put in.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy can be created by friction and heat.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy can only be used for mechanical work.

multiple-choice.question: Why do inventors' ideas for perpetual motion machines fail?

options.label: A
options.text: They don't have enough energy to keep going.

options.label: B
options.text: They violate one or more fundamental laws of thermodynamics.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too complex to build.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not useful.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second law of thermodynamics that prevents a perpetual motion machine from working?

options.label: A
options.text: Energy tends to be created in processes like friction.

options.label: B
options.text: Energy tends to spread out through processes like friction.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy can only be used for mechanical work.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy can be destroyed by friction and heat.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it hard to conclusively say we'll never discover a perpetual motion machine?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we don't understand the laws of thermodynamics.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we don't understand the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we don't know if it's possible to create a machine that doesn't violate the laws of thermodynamics.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we don't know if it's possible to create a machine that doesn't generate friction and heat.
